turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So what do you think?  Should we get a room?

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Should we get a what?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: points at the motel.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Shall we give it a name?

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Dave.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Did you know Dave's a bed wetter?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, I... uh, didn't know that

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: All his life.  He's tried everything.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Still clear?

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: We'll let it run awhile

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Hey Yeah?

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Take me to that motel.  Like you wanted.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Right now?

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Easy, tiger.  Come by after school. I'll leave Darryl with the sitter.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Three twenty-five.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Three twenty-five.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: What do you want, Jim?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You're there.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Yeah.  I'm here.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sherry... I love you.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: Don't say that.  You know it's not true.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It's the only true thing I know anymore.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: We made a mistake.  Let's not make it worse.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: A mistake?  That was no mistake.

turns.speaker: SHERRY
turns.text: I was lonely.  You took advantage

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Me?  I took advantage of you?  You hugged me!  You kissed me!  You're the one who --

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Paul, I know you've been pretty down since your accident.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I wanted to play next year so bad I could taste it.  And maybe go on to...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I know.  I understand disappointment. I really do.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But you've got a big choice right now. You can choose to be depressed about it for the rest of your life. Or you can choose to see it for what it really is: an opportunity.  I personally think you have a big future ahead of you, and I don't mean the fleeting glory of sports.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Let me give you a clue.  You're a born leader.  You're one of the most popular students at Millard.  You're honest and straightforward.  You don't choke under pressure, as we all saw in that amazing fourth quarter against Westside.  The other kids look up to you.  What does that spell?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Who, me?  Nooo.  I never... I don't know anything about that stuff, Mr. M. Besides, that's Tracy Flick's thing. She's always working so hard and --

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah, no, she's a go-getter, all right.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And she's super-nice

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah.  But one person assured of victory kind of undermines the whole idea of a democracy, doesn't it? That's more like a... well, like a dictatorship, like we studied.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Paul, what's your favorite fruit?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Huh?  Oh.  Uh... pears

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: takes a piece of chalk from the lip of the blackboard.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Okay, let's say

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, wait -- apples.  Apples.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Fine.  Let's say all you ever knew was apples.  Apples, apples and more apples. You might think apples were pretty good, even if you occasionally got a rotten one. Then one day there's an orange. And now you can make a decision. Do you want an apple, or do you want an orange? That's democracy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I also like bananas.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Exactly.  So what do you say?  Maybe it's time to give a little something back.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh, no.  No.  I'm just finishing up here, and I've got to get home.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Why don't you guys go sit down, okay? I'll catch up in a minute? I want to talk to Mr. M. about some important stuff.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And on Halloween we could have a haunted house.  But a really good haunted house, not like those cheesy bad ones.  You know, more like the radio station ones.  This one would be really scary.  And for Homecoming -- well, you know how last year's theme was -

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Paul... Paul.... We'll have plenty of time to get into all this later.  A whole year, in fact. Right now I just need to finish my pie and get home.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, okay.  Yeah, sorry.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Just one more thing.  So, Mr. M., uh, do you think Tracy's going to be okay? I saw her face after the assembly, and I think she's taking it pretty hard.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Don't worry about Tracy.  She'll be fine.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: 253... 254... 255. I get the same as you Jim. Looks like Paul's our president.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: No way I It doesn't make sense.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Sorry. My figures work out exactly the same as Jim's. 256 for Paul, 255 for Tracy.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: And 290 "disregards," right?

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: If you say so.

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Whoa! Easy, Fouch. I don't like where you're going.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I'm telling you. Dr. Hendricks, every vote was accounted for.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You said I was a liar   You're the liar, you're the --

turns.speaker: WALT
turns.text: Larry, you just take it easy

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I told you ... I can't. I just -- It doesn't feel right anymore, you know?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Where 're you going?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'm not like you.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'm not a dyke, okay, and we're not in love. We were just... I was just experimenting.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: People can see this.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: These are private -- these are for us.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: But other people can see them too.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Well, I do.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Uhhh... teeth. Teeth.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: We can't both run, can we?  We're brother and sister.  Can we?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's a conflict of interest.  And Paul was first.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: She's doing this to get back at me

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I mean at you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I don't know.  You're her brother you should know.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: We still have some extra ones, don't we?  Maybe we can just --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It was Tammy I  That's who it was.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, no, hey.  Like I said. Tammy wouldn't... she...

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Who put you up to this?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Huh?  Oh, hi, Tracy

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Who put you up to this?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: You just woke up this morning and suddenly decided to run for president?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No.  Uh... I just... you know, I just thought --

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Thought what?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, see, I was talking to Mr. McAllister about my leg and everything... and how I still want to, you know, do something for the school and --

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: So Mr. McAllister asked you to run.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, I mean, you know, I talked to him and everything, but he just said he thought it was a good idea... and how there's all different kinds of fruit and...  It's nothing against you, Tracy. You're the best.  I just thought --

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Okay, Mr. Popular.  You're on.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Way to go, Tracy!  Isn't this exciting?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hell, good luck!

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Good luck to you too, Paul.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Thanks!

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Paul, I just want you to know that no matter how this turns out, you've run a wonderful campaign. It's been fun competing with you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, you too, Tracy.  I'm just glad it's over.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You know, I don't understand why everybody bad-mouthed Tracy all the time.  She was always super- nice to me.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Paul, will you sign my yearbook?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Sure, Tracy.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Can I sign yours too?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, yeah, sure.  Hey Nolan, give my book to Tracy when you're done*

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Yes, Paul?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Have a great summer.  And good luck at college.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Thanks.  You too.  It was great working with you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hey, Tammy, guess what happened today.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Don't you fucking knock?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah.  So guess what happened.  So Mr. McAllister, he --  Oh hi. Lisa.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Paul, get out!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So Mr. M. calls me in and tells me --

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: You dumbshit!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What'd I do?

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: You know how they say one day a big meteor might come and crash into the Earth and kill everybody? Well, I think that would be a good thing.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh.  Hi, Tammy.  I was just, you know, I went to all your teachers and got your assignments.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I just thought, well, last time you got suspended you fell so behind and -

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Okay, Paul.  Thanks.  Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Now could you leave me alone?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah.  Oh, one more thing. Tammy. You know, all this election stuff. 'Cause, you know, everyone is saying it's so weird that you're running against me, and, well, it is kind of weird, and you haven't really told me why you're doing it and didn't tell me in advance or anything.  But that's okay, you know.  l respect your privacy.  I just want you to know that no matter who wins, if it's you or me, there's no hard feelings. We're still brother and sister.  Okay? Cause... and I hope you feel the same.

turns.speaker: TAMMY
turns.text: Sure, Paul.  No hard feelings.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Okay.  Great.  I feel good.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: How's the left these days?

turns.speaker: BOXER
turns.text: What's it to you?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I saw you fight Kid Gavilan.  I like your style.

turns.speaker: BOXER
turns.text: What do you want, Mr. Policeman?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You got a brother up in Folsom.  I know because I put him there.

turns.speaker: BOXER
turns.text: Till 19-fucking-70.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: How'd you like to make it 1960?  I know the judge and Sergeant Exley here is friends with hte D.A.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We're looking for three colored guys who like to pop off shotguns. One of 'em owns a purple Merc coupe.

turns.speaker: BOXER
turns.text: You wanna get me a fuckin' snitch jacket?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You wanna buy your brother ten years...?  You don't have to say anything.  Just look at this list and point.  Here.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Merry Christmas.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Merry Christmas yourself, <u>Officer</u>.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That obvious, huh?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: It's practically stamped on your forehead.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Somebody hit you?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: It's not what you think.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Can I get you a drink?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah, plain scotch.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: I was friendly with Sue Lefferts, but we weren't really friends. You know what I mean?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Are you sorry she's dead?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Of course I am.  What kind of question is that?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Have you ever heard of Dick Stensland?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: No I haven't.  Do you know why Pierce is humoring you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You use words like that, you might make me mad.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Yes.  But do you know?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah I know.  Patchett's running whores and judging by his address, probably something bigger on the side.  He doesn't want any attention.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: That's right.  Our motives are selfish, so we're cooperating.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Why was Susan Lefferts at the Nite Owl?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: I don't know.  I never heard of the Nite Owl till today.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Did Lefferts have a boyfriend?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Like I said we were friendly, not friends.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How'd she meet Patchett?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Pierce meets people.  Sue came on the bus with dreams of Hollywood.  This is how they turned out.  Thanks to Pierce, we still get to act a little.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Tell me about Patchett.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: He's waiting for you to mention mention.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You want some advice, Miss Bracken?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: It's Lynn.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Miss Bracken, don't ever try to fucking bribe me or threaten me or I'll have you and Patchett in shit up to your ears.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: I remember you from Christmas Eve.  You have a thing for helping women, don't you, Officer White?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Maybe I'm just fucking curious.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: You say 'fuck' a lot.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You fuck for money.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: There's blood on your shirt.  Is that an integral part of your job?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Do you enjoy it?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: When they deserve it.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Did they deserve it today?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm not sure.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: But you did it anyway.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah, just like the half dozen guys you screwed today.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Actually, it was two.  You're different, Officer White.  You're the first man in five years who didn't tell me I look like Veronica Lake inside of a minute.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You look better than Veronica Lake.  Now, <u>Pierce Patchett</u>.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: He takes a cut of our earnings and invests it for us.  He makes us quit the life at thirty.  He doesn't let us use narcotics and he doesn't abuse us.  Can your policeman's mentality grasp those contradictions?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: He had you cut to look like Veronica Lake?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: No.  I'm really a brunette, but the rest is me.  And that's all the news that's fit to print.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Look.  I want to see you again.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Are you asking me for a date or an appointment?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: If it's a date I think you'd better tell me your first name because I --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Forget I asked.  It was a mistake.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: I wondered when you might ring the bell again, Officer White.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's Bud.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: It doesn't matter.  All they get is Veronica Lake.  You got the real Lynn Margaret Bracken...  Where'd this come from?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: When I was ten, my old man threw a bottle at my mother.  I guess I got in the way.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: So you saved her.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah.  But not for long.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Do you like being a cop, Bud?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I used to.  What I do now is strong-arm.  Sitting duck stuff... No, I don't like it.  If I could work Homicide like a real detective...

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: You found Patchett.  You found me. You're smart enough.  Be a detective if that's what you want.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That simple, huh?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Did you talk to Exley?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Come in out of the rain.  In the morning we'll have both our stories for breakfast.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I want to know about Exley.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: He's the opposite of you.  He's more like me.  Cold, calculating.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How'd you get to know so much about him?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: Come in out of the rain, Bud.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You gonna tell me what happened with you and Exley?

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: We talked.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: So tell me about it.

turns.speaker: LYNN
turns.text: In the morning.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No.  Now.  You fucked him.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Lad, may I have a word with you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: This business, Captain?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Say goodnight to your friend and join me by those back tables.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Does that paper say we've been indicted?  Does it say Exley's a hero for squealing me and Stensland off?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: He made his play amd he got what he wanted.  They're making him a detective.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Captain, what do you want?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Call me Dudley.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Dudley, what do you want?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Lad, I admire your refusal to testify and your loyalty to your partner.  I admire you as a policeman, particularly your adherence to violence as a necessary adjutant to the job. And I am most impressed with your punishment of wife beaters.  Do you hate them, Wendell?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah, I hate them.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: And for good reason judging from what I know of your background.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What's going to happen to Stensland?  He'll give himself cirrhosis over this.  <u>He's one</u> <u>year from his pension</u>.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: It would've happened years ago if you hadn't carried him.  Why the loyalty, Wendell?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: He helped me out once.  That's all.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Your partner's through. Department scapegoat on the Chief's orders.  He's been billed, he'll be indicted and he'll swing.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Him and me both.  <u>Fucking Exley</u>.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Don't underestimate his skills. As a politician he exceeds even myself.  But the department needs smart men like Exley and... direct men like yourself

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: <u>What do you want</u>?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Wendell, I want you to come to work for me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Doing what?  Mowing your fucking lawn?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: They're yours.  Take them.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I knew you had juice, but... There's no goddamn bill on me?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Four of the defendants recanted their testimony.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: I need you for an assignment the Chief's given me the go-ahead on. A duty few men are fit for, but you were born for.  You'll be working out of Homicide.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Homicide?  A detective?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Will you work for me?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Of course... But how?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: How what, Wendell?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How'd you get them to retract?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Give me one minute.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: You've got it, Wendell.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: You're perplexing to me these days, Wendell.  You're not your old, cruel self anymore.  I need proof that the extracurricular work I had planned for you remains within your grasp.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What work?

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: I've long been involved in containing hard crime in such a way that myself and a few colleagues might someday enjoy a profit dispensation.  That day will soon be here and you'll share handsomely.  Grand means will be in our hands, Wendell.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: Imagine crime limited to the criminal element who perpetrate it. Imagine the means to keep the nigger filth sedated.  But don't stop there.  Extrapolate.  Imagine the police in control.  It's big, lad.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You lost me, Dudley.  I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: DUDLEY
turns.text: You have your extracurricular secrets, I have mine.  We'll hold a clarification session soon.  For now, I need your fearsome old habits at the Victory Motel. We're going to brace a man who may know who killed Jack Vincennes. Can I count on you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure, boss.  Sure you can.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You know him?

turns.speaker: STENSLAND
turns.text: Seen him around.  He used to be a cop.

turns.speaker: STENSLAND
turns.text: Hey, partner.  Grab a cup.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I got to write my report first.

turns.speaker: STENSLAND
turns.text: Don't look so down in the mouth, Bud.  You nailed him good.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah, sure... I got a couple of hours before I have to be at the Victory.  Want to grab a beer?

turns.speaker: STENSLAND
turns.text: Rain check me, partner.  I got something big going on tonight.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What?  That new mystery girl you've been seeing?

turns.speaker: STENSLAND
turns.text: No.  I'll tell you sometime.  Not now.  Don't want to jinx it.  But it could take the edge off that jail time I got coming.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: STENSLAND
turns.text: It's confidential, Bud.  Like that magazines Vincennes scams for. <u>Hush-Hush</u>.  I'll see you tomorrow.  And hey, if it works out, you'll get a piece of it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mrs. Lefferts, I'm Officer White with the L.A.P.D.  I'd like to ask a couple of questions.

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: Let my daughter rest in peace.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Five minutes.  That's all.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Tell me about the boyfriend she had.  The one you mentioned at the morgue.

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: First I want to go on record as saying that my Susie was a virgin when she died.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Ma'am, I'm sure she was.

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: Susie, I told you I didn't approve of that boyfriend.  He was too old for you.  You let him come into this house and be fresh to me.  I went out one day and old Mrs. Jensen next door saw Susan's boyfriend and another man and thought she heard a ruckus.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What was that boyfriend's name?

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: We were never properly introduced. Susan and I were fighting that day.  She called him by a nickname.  Muns or Lunts or something.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Stens?  Was it Stens?

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: Maybe.  I don't know.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Look at a picture for me.

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: That's him.  That's him.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You said a neighbor heard a ruckus.  Was it outside, inside?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What's through here?

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: No!  Please leave!

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: Don't mind the smell.  I think a rat died behind the wall... My Susie was a good girl!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Easy.  Tell me about the ruckus.

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: I came home that night and there was blood on the floor.  Susan said Stams -- Stens had cut himself.  They were acting nervous.  And that Stens kept going under the house.

turns.speaker: MRS. LEFFERTS
turns.text: Was it... a rat?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah.  A great big one.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Where are we going?

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: It's a surprise.  You like surprises, don't you, White?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah, that's Stens.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Hell of a way to avoid a prison sentence.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Someone held up a coffee shop, panicked and killed six people.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: One in six.  Where's the girl?

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Officer White, put down that weapon and --

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: A naked guy with a gun?  You expect anyone to believe that?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Get the fuck away from me.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: How's it going to look on your report?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It'll look like justice.  That's what that fat fuck got.  <u>Justice</u>.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: You don't know what the word means, you dumb bastard.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Lynn.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: She told you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I knew Stensland and Meeks knew each other.  Meeks was with Sue Lefferts on Christmas Eve.  The night I met Lynn.  Lefferts' mother I.D.ed Stensland as Lefferts' boyfriend, but Stens pretended he didn't know either one of them.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Stensland and Meeks.  What were they up to?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Johnny Stompanato told me when Meeks disappeared, he was trying to move the 18 pounds of heroin that went missing when Deuce Perkins was shot.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: <u>Stensland and Buzz Meeks</u>.  Two-man triggers knocking off Mickey Cohen lieutenants.  When they killed Deuce Perkins, they got heroin as a bonus.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Then something goes wrong.  Meeks gets killed.  Maybe Stens got greedy, killed Meeks and left him under his girlfriend's house.  The night he died, Stens was all mysterious.  Said he had something big going down.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: The Nite Owl!  Stensland was going there to sell the heroin.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Somebody got wind of it, killed them all.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: It wasn't the Negroes.  The Griffith Park report was a phony. And, who says the purple Merc was spotted outside the Nite Owl?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Dudley.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: The first guys to the car when Jack and I got there were Bruening and Carlisle.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Dudley's guys.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: They didn't find the shotguns. They planted them.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It all keeps coming back to Dudley.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: It's Dudley for the Nite Owl.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Pierce Patchett figures in, too. That's the angle Jack was working. Dudley must work for Patchett.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Let's just kill them.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: For Jack, for Stensland, for anybody else who got in the way. I've been trying to be smart.  A detective.  But killing those two fuckers, that would be justice.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Stay smart, Bud.  We build a case. We play by the rules.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: There are no rules!  Why the fuck are you doing this?  The Nite Owl made you.  You want to tear all that down.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: With a wrecking ball.  You want to help me swing it?

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Let's go see Pierce Patchett.  Run a good-cop-bad-cop.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Which one are you and which one am I?

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: You expecting problems?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Patchett uses a lot of ex-cop muscle.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: It's a suicide note.  Says he killed Jack because Jack had figured out a pornography scam Patchett was running.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: He had help getting up there.  Two of his fingers are broken.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: We had one thing figured wrong.  I don't think Dudley workd for Patchett.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: At least not anymore.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Patchett's dead.  He sent you after me.  I'd say Dudley's tying up his loose ends.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: <u>Lynn</u>.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Ellis Loew.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What about him?

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Jack thought he was up to his neck in all this.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Bud...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: If I let you go, there'll be ten more lawyers to take your place tomorrow.  They just won't come on the bus, that's all.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: They never made a match on the shotgun serial numbers.  What if Breuning and Carlisle took them from the evidence room?  Couple of cold pieces that had been hanging around a year or two.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: We should check the records, and, we should talk to Lynn.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You wanted to meet here?

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: Me?  You called it.  I got a message that...

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: You figured this was a set-up? And you showed up anyway?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: A lot of bad stuff happened here. It's as good a place as any for it to end.

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: You know, all I ever wanted was to measure up to my father.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I spent years trying not to live down to mine.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: She's fine.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm not asking you.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Are you Pierce Patchett?

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: I am.  Are you soliciting for police charities?  The last time, you people called at my office.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm a homicide detective.  Where were you last night?

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: I was here, hosting a party.  Who was killed and why do you think I can help?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Richard Stensland.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: I don't know him.  Mr...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Officer White.  How about Susan Lefferts?  You know her?

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: You know I do or you wouldn't be here.  How did you find me?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: We met outside Hollywood Liquors on Christmas Eve.  This is where Lynn Bracken's booze bills go.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: Of course...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sue Lefferts died at the Nite Owl. I'm investigating.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Where's the other guy?  Buzz.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: He no longer works for me.  Find Susan's killer, Mr. White. I'll give you a handsome reward. <u>Whatever you desire</u>.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Thanks, but no thanks.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: Against your code?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I don't have one.  Lefferts looked beat-up Christmas Eve, but didn't act it.  How come?

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: Do you care about criminal matters peripheral to Susan's murder?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: Then you wouldn't feel obligated to report them?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: Then listen closely, because I'll only say this once and if it gets repeated, I'll deny it.  I run call girls.  Lynn Bracken is one of them and so was Susan Lefferts. I treat my girls very well.  I have grown daughters, myself, and I don't like the thought of women being hurt.  I sense you share this feeling.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Why were Lefferts' eyes black?

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: I think she'd been hit in the face with a tennis racket.  She is -- was -- a big doubles fan.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You wanna go downtown and discuss this officially?

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: Wait.  Our deal still holds?

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: I needed a Rita Hayworth to fill out my little studio.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What little studio?

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: There's Gardner, Hepburn, Grable, Turner.  Lynn Bracken is my Veronica Lake.  I use girls who look like movie stars.  Sometimes I employ a plastic surgeon.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's why her mother couldn't I.D. her... Jesus fucking Christ.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: No, Mr. White.  Pierce Morehouse Patchett.  Now, I sense you're on your best behavior, but that's all I'll give you.  If you persist, I'll meet you with my attorney. Now, would you like Miss Bracken's address?  I doubt she knows anything, but --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I got her address.

turns.speaker: PATCHETT
turns.text: Of course... this is personal with you, isn't it, Mr. White?

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: Officer White.  I heard you got a hard-on for wife beaters.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: And you fuck people up for a living.  That don't make me you. <u>Capisce</u>, shitbird?

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: Wendell White, how's tricks, <u>paesano</u>?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I ain't your <u>paesano</u>, you wop cocksucker.

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: What do you want, <u>officer</u>?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You remember an ex-cop named Buzz Meeks?  He works for a guy named Patchett.

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: Should I?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: His file listed you as a known associate.  Now spill.

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: Oh, yeah.  That was a long time ago.  Before your day.  The last few years he's been muscle for hire.  But I heard he's disappeared.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: More.

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: More's gonna cost you.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How 'bout I give you your balls back?

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: Before Meeks disappeared he was popping off about trying to move eighteen pounds of heroin.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Bullshit.  Where would a two-bit ex-cop get 18 pounds of heroin?

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: Deuce Perkins.  Mickey C's narcotics lieutenant.  The night he got clipped, eighteen pounds of Mickey's heroin went missing.

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: Meeks is probably in Rio or someplace like that by now.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: He's under a tract house in San Berdoo.  And he don't smell too good.  What happened to the heroin, Johnny?

turns.speaker: STOMPANATO
turns.text: I don't know.  I swear it!

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: Bud White, what brings you down to the basement?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I got a few Nite Owl questions.

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: I don't know if you read the papers, but that case is closed.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm tying up loose ends.  Padding my report.  You know how it goes.

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Anything off.  Anything that didn't make sense.

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: You mean beside the fact that thirty-five out of forty-five rounds were gratuitous?  I can't think of anything.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Whose shoe?

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: Susan Lefferts.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: If she was sitting here, then it's facing the wrong way.  What are these smears in the blood?

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: It looks like she was flailing, trying to get away.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: But she's moving away from the door.  Who was sitting at this table?

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: Dick Stensland.  Had to be dumb panic.  If she knew him she would've been sitting with him... Right?

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: Cotton balls.  I found them just inside the meat locker door.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: <u>Ear plugs</u>.

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: Exactly.  At least one of those animals had the brains to protect his ears.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It doesn't exactly play like dumb panic.

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's like they knew they were going to kill everyone before they went in...

turns.speaker: PINKER
turns.text: Yeah, so...

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: Ed, your observations have been astute.  What's your assessment of this situation?

turns.speaker: EXLEY
turns.text: The public demands justice, sir. This was a full-fledged riot of policemen.  Shift the guilt to men whose pensions are secured.  Force them to retire.  But someone has to swing.  Indict, try and convict Stensland and Bud White.  Secure them jail time.  Feed them to the sharks, sir.  Protect yourself; protect the department.
